qas.question: What does the experience of pain have throughout cultures?
What might an aging adult not respond to the same way as a younger person would?
Aging adult's ability to recognize pain may be blunted by what?
Why may older adults quit doing activities the love?
An older adult may also not report pain because they're scared they may be put on what?
How many dimensions does the cultural experience of pain have?
What condition may cause an older adult to report they are in pain?

plausible_answers.text: they are afraid they will have to have surgery or will be put on a drug they might become addicted to

qas.question: What are reasons a younger adult might refrain from reporting pain?

context: The experience of pain has <b5_0>many<b5_0/> cultural <a0_0>dimensions<a0_0/>. For instance, the way in which one experiences and responds to pain is related to sociocultural characteristics, such as <b6_0>gender, ethnicity, and age.<b6_0/> An aging adult may not respond to <a1_0>pain<a1_0/> in the way that a younger person would. Their ability to recognize pain may be blunted by <a2_0>illness<a2_0/> or the use of multiple prescription drugs. <b7_0>Depression<b7_0/> may also keep the older adult from reporting they are in pain. The older adult may also quit doing activities they love <a3_0>because it hurts too much<a3_0/>. Decline in self-care activities (dressing, grooming, walking, etc.) may also be indicators that the older adult is experiencing pain. The older adult may refrain from reporting pain because <b8_0>they are afraid they will have to have surgery or will be put on <a4_0>a drug<a4_0/> they might become addicted to<b8_0/>. They may not want others to see them as weak, or may feel there is something impolite or shameful in complaining about pain, or they may feel the pain is deserved punishment for past transgressions.
